title: Center for Online Learning
description: Training modules and professional development sessions for UD instructors on a wide variety of topics, including learning technologies and pedagogy.

splash.title: Center for Online Learning
splash.alttext: A view of the Roesch Library's west entrance, looking up at the detached semicircle of columns next to the building.
splash.text: Training modules and professional development sessions for UD instructors on a wide variety of topics, including learning technologies and pedagogy.

paragraphs: Whether you’re a full professor or an adjunct, your teaching has a powerful impact on our students. Today’s students have expectations around how learning technologies can augment their learning. The Center for Online Learning is here to support you in meeting your students’ needs, whether you’re teaching on-campus or asynchronously online.

The custom training programs and materials below will help you stay up-to-date on UD’s essential learning technologies and innovative teaching practices. Take some time to explore and engage with these professional development resources.

badges.title: Participation Trophy
badges.description: Do you earn this badge for doing anything impressive? Nope. All you do is log into the system, and poof! You get the badge. You participated. Take your trophy. You are now prepared for your first steps in the Center for Online Learning's online training. DISCLAIMER: Always consult your physician before beginning any online training program. This is not intended to diagnose any medical condition or to replace your health care professional. If you experience any pain or shortness of breath with these online modules, stop and consult your physician.

badges.title: Is-A-Door
badges.description: Isidore. If you know what it is and you know what it does, it will open all kinds of doors for your teaching career here at UD. The name of the badge will also serve as a reminder of the proper pronunciation. The Center for Online Learning hears a lot of eyes-a-dore and Isadora type stuff. No good! You wouldn't want to bring dishonor on Saint Isidore of Seville, the patron saint of students and the Internet, would you? This badge is awarded for completing the What Is Isidore? lesson.

badges.title: Onboarded
badges.description: Earning this badge proves that you are on-board. You're not the captain of the ship. Heck. You're not even a crew member. But you're on the boat, and you earned your spot by completing the I'm Brand New module.

badges.title: Site Sighted
badges.description: Creating a site in Isidore is the most important thing you will ever do. At any point of your life. No matter what. It may even save your life. This badge is awarded following a validation (or observational sighting) of an Isidore site you created as part of the Course Site Creation lesson.

badges.title: Gen Ed
badges.description: Like the general ed courses for undergrads, this badge is awarded for those that have completed the Isidore 101 modules, which teaches on the fundamental tools of Isidore. And just like those general ed, Isidore 101 prepares you for your next steps in learning Isidore, your next steps in teaching, and your next steps in becoming the best instructor this institution has ever seen!

badges.title: Feelin' Dangerous
badges.description: Have you ever heard the expression, You know enough to be dangerous? Well, that's you right now. This badge is earned following the completion of both the I'm Brand New and Isidore 101 modules. At this point you're ready to start doing some great things with Isidore. But we need to be clear that the dangerous thing is just an expression. We don't suggest you ever put yourself in a position where you feel or create true danger. Just be cool, ok?

badges.title: Header
badges.description: Headers are important in soccer but this badge is awarded to those that know that headers are important in online content as well. Alt text and closed captions are important as well, but they are not used quite as often in soccer. Well, you could probably find some closed captions on a televised soccer match.

badges.title: Creative Caring
badges.description: The CC symbol stands for Closed Captions, but those that earn this badge understand that accessibility is also about Creative Caring. Instructors do not need to suppress their creativity to keep their content accessible. In fact, universal design tends to be best for everyone.

paragraphs: If you’re brand new to Isidore or just need a complete refresher, the lessons in this training module will help you understand everything you need to know to get started with UD’s learning management system (LMS). The topics covered include background information about Isidore, basic navigation and layout of the system, the site creation process, and brief overviews of the most essential tools to facilitate your classes.
Completing this training package should take no longer than 45 minutes. We recommend starting with the first lesson, but you can also jump to any topic to find the specific help you need.
Isidore is UD's open-source Learning Management System or LMS. Isidore is based on the Sakai LMS, but why did UD go this direction? Find out in this lesson.
Now it's time to prove you watched the video. Complete the Quick Quiz below and earn a badge.

contents.title: Wiki Page for St. Isidore of Seville

lessons.title: Getting Started with Isidore
lessons.teaser: Find out how to log in and use the homepage.

paragraphs: The Isidore homepage is designed to help you see summarized information about all of your classes on one page, similar to a dashboard. In this video, you’ll learn how to log in and about each of the components on your homepage.
Now it's time to prove you watched the video. Complete the Quick Quiz below and earn a badge.

lessons.title: Setting Up Your Course Site
lessons.teaser: Learn how to create Isidore sites.

paragraphs: There are several different approaches for creating Isidore sites. In this Lesson, we’ll provide guidance on which site creation path you should take, as well as demonstrations of each workflow. We’ll then review how to create an attractive and informative landing page with an up-to-date syllabus and schedule.

As an instructor, you should create an Isidore site for each of your course sections. In this video, you’ll learn how to create a site from scratch, how to duplicate an existing site, and how to create a site from a template - and how to determine which option is best for your needs.
You will now create your own Isidore site. If you would like to create a site for an actual course, you can follow the steps shown in the video.
Log in to Isidore.
Create an Isidore site.
Let us know your site's title by completing the Quick Write below these steps.
A Center for Online Learning staff member will verify that you created a site, then, boom! You earned a Site Sighted badge!
Once you have created a site, submit the site to the Quick Write below to earn your Site Sighted badge.
Take the three question quiz below to show us you know how to create Isidore sites.
The Overview page for your course is the page students will see every time they access your site. It should be organized and informative so students know exactly how to get started with your class.
Take the three question quiz below to show us you know how to add the Cheer Cup widget to your Overview.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: Blog: Common Uses of Commons in Isidore

pages.title: Syllabus and Schedule
pages.description: Modify the UD syllabus and schedule templates.

paragraphs: Use the syllabus and schedule templates to ensure you have the most up-to-date University policies, services, and dates.

pages.title: Site Info
pages.description: Manage your site settings and tools.

paragraphs: The Site Info tool allows you to add tools and manage participants in your Isidore course site. It provides other customizations and controls as well so you can make sure your site is dialed into your specifications.

pages.title: Text Editor
pages.description: Format text, post pictures, and embed videos.

paragraphs: The text editor is far more powerful than just a tool for adding formatted text. With this tool, you can post pictures, upload files, embed videos, write math equations, and insert visually interesting templates.
The video was just a sample of all that is possible with the rich-text editor. Play around with the buttons yourself to see all that's possible. Only then will you be able to pass the quiz.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: The Human Touch and Your Digital Personality

paragraphs: There are many ways to stay in touch with students. Announcements are a great option because it keeps the posts organized within Isidore while also generating an email to the students’ UD inboxes.
Take the three question quiz below to establish your Announcements expertise.
Wiki Resources
Additional Articles

contents.title: Blog: The Power of Asking How You’re Doing

paragraphs: The Resources tool is a required tool in your Isidore site, meaning you can't delete it. This is because any attachment, file, or cat picture you add to your site is actually stored in the Resources tool, whether you know it or not. While Resources isn't the only tool you can use to share course materials with your students, it's the easiest to get started with.
Take a three question quiz to demonstrate your understanding of Resources.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: UD Students Answer: What is the Single Most Important Thing an Instructor Can Do in Isidore?

pages.title: Roster
pages.description: Review who is in your class.

paragraphs: The Roster tool helps you get to know your students. Use the features within the tool to memorize students’ names with their faces, hear their name pronunciation recordings, and see their majors and minors. You can also see when students last visited your Isidore course site.
This quiz is easier than memorizing all your students' names, but it’s fun to try that anyway.
Wiki Resources
Additional Articles

contents.title: Pronouncing Students’ Names Correctly Should Be a Big Deal
The Importance of Learning Students’ Names

paragraphs: Help students stay accountable and keep track of their attendance by recording it in Isidore. The default settings let you mark a student as present, absent, excused, late, or left early. You may also add comments to individual student’s attendance records to help you remember why they were absent or excused. The tool also allows you to customize your categories of attendance and add grading options.
Learn how to print a sign-in or attendance taking sheet.
Log in to Isidore.
Navigate to an Isidore site.
Create an Attendance item.
Click on the Actions button and choose Print.
Print either a Sign-In or an Attendance sheet.
You might be tempted to skip this quiz, but you shouldn’t. There’s a big time-saving tip in it!
Wiki Resources
Additional Articles

pages.title: Calendar
pages.description: Manage course due dates with the Calendar tool.

paragraphs: Students tell us that the second most important tool in Isidore is the Calendar (after the Gradebook, of course!). Learn how you can create course Calendar entries that help students stay on track.
Reinforce your learning of the Calendar tool in this two question quiz.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons

pages.title: Assignments
pages.description: Post and collect written submissions from students.

paragraphs: Keep your students’ submissions organized within Isidore by posting the instructions with open and due dates in the Assignments tool. Once students electronically submit their writing, you can provide feedback, grades, and allow students to revise and resubmit.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: Blog: Reducing Grading Load with Model Answers
How to Give Your Students Better Feedback in Less Time

paragraphs: Create online tests and quizzes with a huge amount of question types, which in most cases are automatically graded. Scores can be sent to the gradebook, and students will be able to see valuable feedback.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: Writing Good Multiple Choice Test Questions

pages.title: Lessons Template
pages.description: Organize course materials within the Lessons template.

paragraphs: If you have created your Isidore site based on a template, your site will contain weekly pages that are date-released throughout the semester. Within each page is a section where you can write out the tasks for the week as well as develop a checklist that students can use to keep themselves on track. If you use this template, we recommend hiding the Resources tool so students know to look for all course materials within the Lessons tool.
Wiki Resources
Additional Articles

contents.title: Blog: Keeping Your Students on Track with Checklists

paragraphs: The Isidore Gradebook tool allows you to enter grades for individual students, then it automatically performs grade calculations based on your preferences. Students are able to view their grades (and only their own grades!) and appreciate it when you keep everything up-to-date.
Wiki Resources
Related Lessons
Additional Articles

contents.title: Video: What Do UD Students Think About Grades?

paragraphs: This set of lessons introduces the concepts of digital accessibility in the context of teaching here at the University of Dayton. Additional Resources are provided with each module to provide optional, in-depth training to complete your understanding of how to make all of your course content accessible.

lessons.title: Visual Disabilities
lessons.teaser: How can you make your content accessible for students with visual impairments?

paragraphs: Students with profound visual impairments use screen reading software to read files and web pages. How does this inform the way you construct and organize your content? And how does color-blindness affect your use of color?
This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with visual impairments.
Resources
Related Lessons
In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Visual Disabilities Quiz

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
How detailed should I be when writing alt text for an image?
Be brief, but be sure to describe the essential elements of the image. If the graphic is supposed to make the audience think or feel something, be sure your alt text leads that direction.
Should I always start with H1?

This gets tricky. The main thing is that you use header tags. That's 99% of the battle. Often Isidore has existing headers already in place. In most cases in Isidore, it's recommended you start with H2.

The Center for Online Learning has invited expert screen-reader users to evaluate Isidore. Additionally, Isidore is based on the open source LMS Sakai, which has accessibility as crucial foundation of the software.

lessons.title: Auditory Disabilities
lessons.teaser: How can you make your content accessible for students with hearing impairments?

paragraphs: Videos have two components, images and sound. For students with hearing impairments, you will need to ensure that all audio components are "captured" and presented to students. This is most often in the form of closed captioning. The bonus is that captions are part of universal design and are beneficial to every type of learner.

This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with hearing impairments, and it also explains how captions can be beneficial to students without hearing impairments.
Resources

contents.title: How to Locate Captioned Videos and Create Your Own
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Closed Captioning

paragraphs: Related Lessons
In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Auditory Disabilities Quiz

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
Do I have to pay for captions?
Not if it's for a course. If you upload videos to Warpwire for the purpose of providing instructional content, the Center for Online Learning will take care of the captions for you.
How can I ensure the captions are accurate?
You are still responsible for the accuracy of the captions, so please check them. If you find inaccuracies please contact the Center for Online Learning.

Warpwire videos can actually be searched. For example, if you wanted to search a video for the moment the speaker says the word, 'Malaysia', you just click the search icon type 'Malaysia'. This is possible due to the presence of captions.

lessons.title: Cognitive, Motor, & Other Disabilities
lessons.teaser: How can you make your content accessible for students with cognitive, motor, and other disabilities?

paragraphs: Many of the accessibility techniques you use for people with visual disabilities are helpful for individuals with cognitive and motor disabilities, but putting extra attention on organization and clarity is definitely something you should prioritize.
This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with cognitive and motor disabilities. There also is discussion on content for students with seizure disorders.
Resources
Related Lessons
In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Other Disabilities Quiz

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
What if my content is inherently complex?
It's not about how complicated your content is, but rather how clearly you present it. Be organized. Use headers and spacing appropriately.
What if a student is lacking in basic study skills?
Direct them to contact the Office of Learning Resources or contact the Student Success Team.
A study revealed that simply presenting the same instructions in an easier to read font, caused students to see the tasks as easier. Clarity and organization make a difference.

lessons.title: Accessible Documents
lessons.teaser: How can you make your files, such as Word and Powerpoint, accessible for students with disabilities?

paragraphs: All documents utilized in class must be made available in electronic format to students. This is important not just for students with visual and hearing impairments but for all students who may have academic accommodations for attention issues and processing disorders. This impacts approximately 5-10 percent of students. What steps must you take to ensure that the electronic version is completely accessible?
This video explains the essentials for delivering accessible files.
Resources

contents.title: Microsoft Word Training on Accessibility in Word
Microsoft Word Training on Accessibility in PowerPoint
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Closed Captioning
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Accessible Documents

paragraphs: Related Lessons
In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Accessible Documents Quiz

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
What do I do if my existing documents are not accessible?

In the Additional Resources, you'll see a link to Sensus Access. This can be very useful in terms of converting text that is unreadable to readable text. It will not necessarily convert all headings and it certainly won't put alt text in there, but it gives you a good base to start from.
I don't like the way the headers look in MS Word, can I change the look?
You bet! In the ribbon you can right mouse click on the header you want to change and it will change it for all instances of the header.
Google Docs and Slides also have the same general accessible properties as their Microsoft Office counterparts.

lessons.title: Accessibility of Outside Materials
lessons.teaser: If you intend to use materials that you do not produce yourself, how can you be sure they are accessible?

paragraphs: Most faculty include some externally produced content in their course required course materials. This could be articles from the web, YouTube videos, publisher resources, and software. If you are requiring your students to use it, you need to be sure it is accessible.
This video explains the essentials for ensuring outside materials are accessible.
Resources

contents.title: How to Find Specialized Formats of Print Materials
How to Select Accessible Digital Materials

paragraphs: Related Lessons
In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Outside Materials Quiz

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
My chair picked my materials, what if they're not accessible?
Say something, but be tactful about it. Offer to contact the vendor or publisher. Your chair can later decide whether you'll continue with those materials.
How can I ensure the captions are accurate?
You are still responsible for the accuracy of the captions, so please check them. If you find inaccuracies please contact the Center for Online Learning.
Most electronic textbooks are accessible, and they also tend to be cheaper. Just remember to check before you buy.

What is Warpwire and why should I use video in my course site?

Warpwire is a secure video storage and sharing product. The tool is a great way to optimize your videos for easy streaming by students in your course site. Anyone with a valid UD username and password can easily upload videos and share them with UD and non-UD users — anywhere, anytime, on just about any modern device. Warpwire is accessible via a secure website or an Isidore course site.

video.title: Introduction Learn Warpwire
video.description: In this video we discuss how video can enhance your course site with video and how to share them via Warpwire. We provide a basic introduction to Warpwire and its most common uses and purpose.

lessons.title: The Basics of Warpwire
lessons.teaser: Learn how to add the Warpwire tool and upload content.

paragraphs: Warpwire is a fairly simple tool to operate. Taking a bit of time to work through the lessons in this module will answer most questions that you might have or encounter as you use the tool. The main steps to use of Warpwire are to upload and share videos. Let’s learn how.
Adding Warpwire to your Course site and Uploading / Copying Videos
In this lesson we will cover how to install the Warpwire tool to your course site and upload your first video to Warpwire. We will show you how to copy your videos from one site to another.

video.title: Adding Warpwire to your Course site and Uploading/Copying Videos

paragraphs: Add Warpwire to one of your course sites and upload a video.
To complete this task, please follow the instructions below. To receive credit, please submit the quick write question after completing the task.

Choose one of your current or past course sites for this task. If you have not taught a course in Isidore before and need a demo site created for you, please email onlinelearning@udayton.edu with a request for a site.
Click on “Add Tool” in the left hand menu of your course site under the “Site Info” heading.
Click the box to the left of the menu item “Warpwire” in the Core Tools section of the Add/Remove Tools menu.
Click Continue at the bottom of the page.
Click Finish at the bottom of the subsequent page. This will place Warpwire as a menu item in your course site.
Click on Warpwire Video in the left hand menu of your site.
Click the “+” sign in the upper right corner of the tool window to choose to upload a video.
Click the menu option “Upload Files”. This will open up the file picker on your computer.
Navigate to find the video you would like to upload, select, and click Open.
Rename the video if desired in the next screen and click “Start Uploading”. This will automatically upload your video to the Warpwire Library.
Tell us about your experience
Use the Quick Write below to tell us about your site and how easy or difficult you found this task.

lti.description: Complete the following Quick Write task.
lti.title: Add Warpwire and Upload a Video

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
How do I create my own videos?

You can create your own videos using any video recording tool you have access to. Popular ways of doing this is by using Snagit which is a screen capture software that we are happy to provide faculty a license for. Other alternatives are to use your camera phone, a camera with video recording capabilities, or other software that came with your computer. For suggestions on creating quality lecture videos please see this help video.
Do students view videos directly from the Warpwire tool?

Students can be directed to the Warpwire tool to view videos but we recommend embedding the videos or links to the videos within lessons. This is explained and demonstrated in Lesson four of this series.
How long can my videos be?

We recommend creating lecture videos that are no longer than 10-15 minutes, but acknowledge that sometimes it’s necessary for videos to be longer than this. The maximum file size that can be uploaded is 10 GB.
Can students upload videos to the Library?

Students can upload to the Warpwire tool. Before doing so, you must grant them permission to do so as directed in the instructions on our eWiki page. You will want to give students clear instructions on the correct labeling/naming procedure before uploading to help with organization.
Online Learning Support Resources

contents.title: Upload a video from my computer
Upload a video from my phone or mobile device
Record a video with my webcam
Record a video with my mobile device
Copy a video between Isidore sites

paragraphs: Warpwire Support

contents.title: Getting Started with Warpwire in Sakai (Isidore)
Upload and Insert Media in Sakai (Isidore)

paragraphs: Additional Resources

contents.title: Combine Synchronous and Asynchronous Instruction During your Class Time
Online Teaching Best Practices for Web Lectures and Presentations

lessons.title: Settings and Organization
lessons.teaser: Learn how to rename, replace, tag, and sort the videos in your Warpwire libraries.

paragraphs: Storing your videos in Warpwire is a great start, but there are many customization options in the settings of your library and in the settings of your individual videos.  Understanding the options and reasons behind different settings will help you make the most of your Warpwire library.
Customization using Warpwire Settings

In this lesson we will review how to organize and manage your Warpwire library by renaming videos, updating a video with a newer version, tagging videos with category names, and changing share and view settings.

video.title: Renaming, replacing, tagging, sorting, and changing the thumbnail for your videos.

paragraphs: Let’s practice a couple of the organization techniques we reviewed in the video.
Add a tag to a video in your Warpwire library.
Navigate to the course site where you added Warpwire and uploaded a video in Lesson One.
Click on the circle with the three dots in the bottom right of the video and choose the menu option “settings”.
Click on the button link that says “Add” that is next to “Tags”
Click “Create Tag”
Type the name of the new tag in the text box window.
Click Create Tag.
Click X to log out of the tag management tool.
Add tags to any other videos you have added to your library.
To sort by tag - click the AZ button icon in the top right corner of your Warpwire library.
Choose to sort by tag.
Rename one of your videos.
Navigate to the course site where you added Warpwire and uploaded a video in Lesson One.
Click on the circle with the three dots in the bottom right of the video and choose the menu option "settings".
Highlight the current name listed under “Title” and hit delete or start typing the new name.
Close the Settings Menu.
Tell us about your experience
Complete this two question survey to let us know about your experience organizing videos in Warpwire.

lti.description: Take the two question survey below to tell us about your experience.
lti.title: Organizing Your Warpwire Videos Survey

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
If I sort my videos by tag will students also see my library in the way I have organized it?

Each individual user has complete control over how they sort their Warpwire library. That means, that even though you are the administrator of your own library, those with access to it will see it in the order they choose. The default order is by date added to the library.  We highly recommend embedding your videos within the lessons tool so that students access the correct videos at the correct time. See Lesson three on embedding videos in lessons.
Can I change my Video's thumbnail?

A Warpwire video automatically selects a screen capture from the video to use as its thumbnail image. Sometimes this selected image is not an ideal choice, or captures one’s image in a non-flattering view. Luckily this can be changed in the Settings menu, allowing you to pick any screen capture from the video.
How do I rename my video?

When uploading videos to Warpwire, they are often populated with the default title of the video file. Oftentimes  this can be a series of letters and numbers, especially with Zoom downloads. You have the opportunity to change the title at the time of upload, however, if you forget to make this change, or wish to re-title your video later; you have the option to do so in the settings menu. For ease of use, we recommend using a standardized naming convention, such as: Module 1, Lesson 1- Introduction or M1 L1 Intro. This makes embedding videos much easier.
How do I update a setting on all my videos at once?

You can do a bulk update to videos by clicking on the open circle in the upper right corner of your Warpwire library, and then either click the  select all button underneath to select all videos in the library or  select few by clicking on the circle underneath the individual videos you wish to apply the setting to. Then in the batch actions drop down menu choose which action you would like to take.
Warpwire Support Resources

contents.title: Upload and insert media in Sakai (Isidore)
Understanding the Terminology of Warpwire Libraries

lessons.title: Embedding Videos in Isidore
lessons.teaser: Learn about the various ways you can embed Warpwire videos in Isidore.

paragraphs: If you use videos in your course on a weekly basis, embedding them into a weekly lesson plan is the best way to ensure your students find your videos easily at the right time. In fact, this allows you to embed them in context with application questions (see lesson four).Students appreciate finding their videos in context with the week’s topics, reading and resources.
Embedding in Lessons and other tools
This lesson steps you through the various ways to embed your videos in your lessons. We also discuss the importance of the settings for share and visibility in your Warpwire library.

video.title: Sharing Videos: Embedding in Lessons and other tools

paragraphs: Embed one video in a lessons page of a course site.
Before completing this assignment, you will need to make sure you have a Lessons Tool included in your course site. If you do not, please follow the directions found on this help page to add Lessons.
Go to Lessons in your course site.
Click the “Add Content” tab or click on the + sign at the top or bottom of a section on your lesson page.
Choose to add “text, video, or image”.
Click the circle icon with a W in the middle of it to the right of center in  the middle line of the editor. This will open your Warpwire library.
Click the circle next to the Warpwire video you want to embed on the page.
Click the “insert item” bar at the bottom of the window.
Click save on your text box.
Review your lessons page for your new embed.
Please send us the address of your course site (or your course site name) along with the name of the lesson page on which you embedded your video.

lti.description: Complete the following Quick Write task.
lti.title: Embed a Warpwire Video in Lessons

paragraphs: Potential Questions You May Have:
Why is it better to embed my videos in lessons rather than directing students to view my video in the Warpwire library?
Placing your videos in the order they are to be watched and in the week or module of lessons in which they occur will help to increase viewership and eliminate confusion on part of the student.
Should I embed my Warpwire videos as a link or an embed?

This is your preference. Use the format that works best for your course layout on the site. The feedback we hear from students and instructors indicates that the embed is the preferred method as it is clear that there is a video to be watched. Links can be overlooked easily.
What if I need to share just a portion of my video?
You can make a clip of a video or audio. Follow the directions in this document.
What if I would like to hide my Warpwire Tool in the menu so that students do not see the tool at all?
To hide Warpwire from your tool menu, Click on Site Info, then Manage Tools. Next to Warpwire Video, click the tool settings icon on the right and choose to “Make Tool Invisible to Students”.
Online Learning Support Resources

contents.title: Insert a video into a forum post

lessons.title: Increasing Interactivity with Videos
lessons.teaser: Learn about the Interactive Video Learning App and explore analytics.

paragraphs: Instructional videos are more effective when you include interactive components. You can do this with embedded questions within lessons or by using the interactive video tool. Instructors can check student analytics on video views through the Warpwire library as well.
Interactive Video and Analytics

In this video we will show you how to use the interactive video tool application, how to add questions within lessons associated with your video and how to check the analytics of viewership of your video lessons.
Using a video you uploaded to your site’s Warpwire library in Lesson One, embed the video within the lessons tool using the interactive video learning app.
Embed an Interactive Video Learning App into Your Lesson
Configure the Interactive Video
Preview your Interactive Video
Potential Questions You May Have:
Can you grade the questions or interactive video and send them to the gradebook?
You can send grades from the interactive video to the gradebook. To learn more about interactive video and how to use it, please see our eWiki help site.
Can I use the interactive video tool with a YouTube video?
That is another yes! You will be able to select either Warpwire or YouTube when setting up your interactive video.
What types of questions can I ask using the Interactive Video tool?

You can ask multiple choice questions, including true/false. If you want to utilize open ended questions, we recommend embedding the quick write or pre/post write learning apps in conjunction with your video.
Online Learning Support Resources

contents.title: How to utilize the Interactive Video learning app
How to embed a question in lessons after a video to assess learning
Embed through a learning app: Pre/Post Reflection
Embed through a learning app: Quick Write
Embed through a learning app: Quick Quiz

lessons.title: Creating Central Course Libraries
lessons.teaser: Create a central library for your course videos.

paragraphs: There can be some confusion about where your videos “live” once placed into a site and embedded into lessons. We recommend that if you plan on using the same or similar videos each term for the same course that you make a “Central Course Library” for your videos and use this each term for each course site. With this approach, you always know where to find your original video and can easily update any video without having to re-embed the video in your lessons tool of the site. This also makes checking the analytics for videos for all course sections at once a breeze!
Creating Central Course Libraries

In this lesson we show you how to create a central library for your course videos. We discuss how to embed videos from this library, update videos to newer versions, and check analytics for a specific date range.
Create a Central Library and Copy Videos from a Previous Course Site to the Library.
Potential Questions You May Have:
Why do I need a central course video library?

A central course library will help to keep track of where your videos are located and maintain them in one location for all of your course sites. When a video needs to be added or updated, it only needs to be added to this one library and then linked in your course site.  Using a Central Course Library for your course site also frees up the Warpwire library in your own site for student uploads of video presentations.
Can I still check analytics on a video within a Central Course Library?
Yes you can. Analytics can be filtered by date, exported and then sorted by viewer. This will help to give you current information on the engagement with videos within the library.
Can I use videos in a central course library with the interactive video tool?
Yes you can!  Videos in the central course library can be selected when setting up the interactive video tool in a course site. How to do this is demonstrated in the video in this lesson.
Support Resources

contents.title: How to create a Media Library
Copy a video between Isidore sites
How to grant students access to upload videos to Warpwire

lessons.title: Analytics in Warpwire
lessons.teaser: Learn how to see which students are watching which parts of your videos.

paragraphs: When you publish a video as part of your lesson, you want to ensure that students have taken the time to watch the instruction. Detailed analytics are available within Warpwire both as a quick view and as a detailed export. Reports allow you to see which students are watching the videos and which parts of the videos they are watching.
Analytics in Warpwire
In this lesson we will demonstrate how to check student viewership of Warpwire videos within a course site and how to embed videos as graded activities based on views.
Embed a Warpwire video in a lessons tool in your course site using the procedure below to make it a graded activity.
Make sure that the Gradebook tool is already installed in your course site. If it is not, please install using the “Add Tool” function in the left hand menu of your course site.
Navigate to the location in lessons where you want to embed a Warpwire video that will be graded based on student viewership.
Click the add content button or the + button.
Choose to "Add Learning App".
In the pop-up window, choose the Warpwire link.
Click Launch External Tool Configuration link.
Click the circle next to the video you would like to embed. If your video is in a different Warpwire library, navigate  to that library and then click the circle next to the correct video.
Click "insert item".

If you would like to embed a video as a thumbnail, rather than a link, you will need to edit the settings of your newly created link by clicking on the edit icon next to the link, choosing display option, click on embed on page, and insert a value of 300-600 in the height box.
Potential Questions You May Have:
How reliable are the analytics on Warpwire videos?

The analytics on Warpwire videos are very reliable if students access videos directly through the embedded link of your video in lessons. If you share your video externally and it has a public setting, viewers may be listed as “anonymous” so avoid having students access the video outside of Isidore.
How do I know that my student watched the video while it played on their computer?

It is possible that even though a student’s analytics show that the student watched the full video, they may not have maintained full attention. We recommend that if you are concerned with this possibility you utilize the interactive video learning app discussed in Lesson 4.
Support Resources

modules.title: Backstage Tour: Media Studio
modules.description: Come try out the LTC’s new video production lab and podcast studio and learn how you can take your teaching to the next level with media innovation.
modules.imagealt: A person looking at two computer monitors.
learningoutcomes: Be familiar with the video production lab and podcast studio
Understand the media resources that are available

modules.title: Students are Cheating with ChatGPT. Now What?
modules.description:
It’s likely you’ve already encountered AI-generated writing in assignment submissions - or suspect they have. We’ll provide an overview of how these tools work and invite faculty to share your tales of woe and wisdom in dealing with ChatGPT over the past year.

AI writing tools are here for good (or ill). In this three-part series we’ll explore teaching in an AI world: How do natural language processing tools work? What do they mean for written assessment and academic honesty? How can we adapt our academic endeavors to capitalize on the benefits and minimize the risks?
modules.imagealt: Young adults sitting in a group smiling on a porch.

modules.title: Are Written Assignments Dead?
modules.description:
Our instructional designers will share what the current research has to say about writing in an AI world. Together we’ll (re)think about creating and grading written assessments and consider some alternatives.

AI writing tools are here for good (or ill). In this three-part series we’ll explore teaching in an AI world: How do natural language processing tools work? What do they mean for written assessment and academic honesty? How can we adapt our academic endeavors to capitalize on the benefits and minimize the risks?
modules.imagealt: Three people looking at laptops sitting at the same table.

modules.title: Joining Forces with ChatGPT
modules.description:
If AI-generated writing isn’t going anywhere, how can we work in harmony with this powerful new tool? We’ll consider the ethics of AI-informed teaching, learning and scholarship; ways to prepare your course for AI; and strategies for using AI tools in ways that will benefit your students and research.

AI writing tools are here for good (or ill). In this three-part series we’ll explore teaching in an AI world: How do natural language processing tools work? What do they mean for written assessment and academic honesty? How can we adapt our academic endeavors to capitalize on the benefits and minimize the risks?
modules.imagealt: A person showing their laptop screen to another person.

modules.title: Isidore Help Lab
modules.description: During these virtual drop-in hours, our support team will be on hand to answer any questions you have about Isidore as you prep your class for the upcoming semester.
modules.imagealt: A person sitting at a table and discussing something with another person.

modules.title: Tools for Teaching: Lightning Round
modules.description: As you prepare your class for a new cohort of students, consider adding a tool or two to your pedagogical repertoire. In this fast-paced session, our instructional designers will cover 10 topics, each in 5 minutes. You’re sure to leave with something new to try!
modules.imagealt: A person sitting an smiling at the camera with a classroom in the background.

modules.title: Mastering Slide Design: Impactful Visuals
modules.description: Truth? Most people are bad at slide design. But we don’t have to be. In this session we’ll look at statistically-backed best practices in slide design, including layout, font / color selection, and custom backgrounds. We’ll even look at some AI design options. Bring your laptop and a slide presentation you’d like to improve and practice as we go.
modules.imagealt: A teacher pointing to a screen in front of a class of young students.
